name: angular
description:
The Nx Plugin for Angular contains executors, generators, and utilities for managing Angular applications and libraries within an Nx workspace. It provides: 

- Integration with libraries such as Storybook, Jest, ESLint, Tailwind CSS, Cypress, Karma, and Protractor. 

- Generators to help scaffold code quickly (like: Micro Frontends, Libraries, both internal to your codebase and publishable to npm) 

- Upgrading AngularJS applications 

- Single Component Application Modules (SCAMs) 

- NgRx helpers. 

- Utilities for automatic workspace refactoring.

documentation.name: Overview
documentation.content:
![Angular logo](/shared/angular-logo.png)

The Nx Plugin for Angular contains executors, generators, and utilities for managing Angular applications and libraries within an Nx workspace. It provides:

- Integration with libraries such as Storybook, Jest, Cypress, Karma, and Protractor.
- Generators to help scaffold code quickly, including:
  - Micro Frontends
  - Libraries, both internal to your codebase and publishable to npm
  - Upgrading AngularJS applications
  - Single Component Application Modules (SCAMs)
- NgRx helpers.
- Utilities for automatic workspace refactoring.

{% callout type="note" title="Currently using the Angular CLI?" %}
You can easily and mostly **automatically migrate from an Angular CLI** project to Nx! Learn more [here](/recipe/migration-angular).
{% /callout %}

## Setting up the Angular plugin

Adding the Angular plugin to an existing Nx workspace can be done with the following:

```bash
yarn add -D @nrwl/angular
```

```bash
npm install -D @nrwl/angular
```

## Using the Angular Plugin

### Generating an application

It's straightforward to generate an Angular application:

```bash
nx g @nrwl/angular:app appName
```

By default, the application will be generated with:

- ESLint as the linter.
- Jest as the unit test runner.
- Cypress as the E2E test runner.

We can then serve, build, test, lint, and run e2e tests on the application with the following commands:

```bash
nx serve appName
nx build appName
nx test appName
nx lint appName
nx e2e appName
```

### Generating a library

Generating an Angular library is very similar to generating an application:

```bash
nx g @nrwl/angular:lib libName
```

By default, the library will be generated with:

- ESLint as the linter.
- Jest as the unit test runner.

We can then test and lint the library with the following commands:

```bash
nx test libName
nx lint libName
```

Read more about:

- [Creating Libraries](/more-concepts/creating-libraries)
- [Library Types](/more-concepts/library-types)
- [Buildable and Publishable Libraries](/more-concepts/buildable-and-publishable-libraries)

## More Documentation

- [Angular Nx Tutorial](/angular-tutorial/01-create-application)
- [Migrating from the Angular CLI](recipe/migration-angular)
- [Setup Module Federation with Angular and Nx](/recipe/faster-builds)
- [Using NgRx](/recipe/misc-ngrx)
- [Using Data Persistence operators](/recipe/misc-data-persistence)
- [Upgrading an AngularJS application to Angular](/recipe/migration-angularjs)
- [Using Tailwind CSS with Angular projects](/recipe/using-tailwind-css-with-angular-projects)

documentation.name: Angular and Nx Version Matrix
documentation.content:
# Nx and Angular Version Compatibility Matrix

Below is a reference table that matches versions of Angular to the version of Nx that is compatible with it. The table shows the version of Angular, the recommended version of Nx to use and the range of Nx versions that support the version of Angular.

We provide a recommended version, and it is usually the latest minor version of Nx in the range provided because there will have been bug fixes added since the first release in the range.

| Angular Version | **Nx Version _(recommended)_** | Nx Version _(range)_ |
| --------------- | ------------------------------ | -------------------- |
| ^8.0.0          | **8.12.2**                     | 8.7.0 <= 8.12.2      |
| ^9.0.0          | **9.6.0**                      | 8.12.4 <= 9.6.0      |
| ^10.0.0         | **10.4.15**                    | 9.7.0 <= 10.4.15     |
| ^11.0.0         | **12.2.0**                     | 11.0.0 <= 12.2.0     |
| ^12.0.0         | **13.1.4**                     | 12.3.0 <= 13.1.4     |
| ^13.0.0         | **14.1.9**                     | .13.2.0 <= 14.1.9    |
| ~14.0.0         | **14.4.3**                     | 14.2.1 <= 14.4.3     |
| ~14.1.0         | **14.5.10**                    | 14.5.0 <= 14.5.10    |
| ~14.2.0         | **14.6.0**                     | 14.6.0 <= latest     |

If you would like to see how the supported versions of Node and Typescript for the version of Angular you are using, [Lars Gyrup Brink Nielsen](https://twitter.com/LayZeeDK) has a very good resource for that [here](https://gist.github.com/LayZeeDK/c822cc812f75bb07b7c55d07ba2719b3).

generators.name: add-linting

schema.title: Add linting to an Angular project.
schema.description: Adds linting configuration to an Angular project.

prefix.description: The prefix to apply to generated selectors.

projectRoot.description: The path to the root of the selected project.

setParserOptionsProject.description: Whether or not to configure the ESLint `parserOptions.project` option. We do not do this by default for lint performance reasons.

generators.description: Adds linting configuration to an Angular project.

generators.name: application

schema.title: Creates an Angular application.
schema.description: Creates an Angular application.

name.x-prompt: What name would you like to use for the application?

directory.description: The directory of the new application.

style.description: The file extension to be used for style files.

x-prompt.message: Which stylesheet format would you like to use?

routing.x-prompt: Would you like to configure routing for this application?

inlineStyle.description: Specifies if the style will be in the ts file.

inlineTemplate.description: Specifies if the template will be in the ts file.

prefix.description: The prefix to apply to generated selectors.

skipPostInstall.description: Do not add or append `ngcc` to the `postinstall` script in `package.json`.

unitTestRunner.description: Test runner to use for unit tests.

e2eTestRunner.description: Test runner to use for end to end (E2E) tests. The `protractor` option is deprecated and it will be removed in v15.

tags.description: Add tags to the application (used for linting).

linter.description: The tool to use for running lint checks.

backendProject.description: Backend project that provides data to this application. This sets up `proxy.config.json`.

strict.description: Create an application with stricter type checking and build optimization options.

standaloneConfig.description: Split the project configuration into `<projectRoot>/project.json` rather than including it inside `workspace.json`.

port.description: The port at which the remote application should be served.

setParserOptionsProject.description: Whether or not to configure the ESLint `parserOptions.project` option. We do not do this by default for lint performance reasons.

addTailwind.description: Whether to configure Tailwind CSS for the application.

skipDefaultProject.description: Skip setting the project as the default project. When `false` (the default), the project is set as the default project only if there is no default project already set.

standalone.description: Generate an application that is setup to use standalone components.

generators.description: Creates an Angular application.

generators.name: component

schema.title: Angular Component Schema
schema.description: Creates a new, generic Angular component definition in the given or default project.

path.description: The path at which to create the component file, relative to the current workspace. Default is a folder with the same name as the component in the project root.

name.x-prompt: What name would you like to use for the component?

displayBlock.description: Specifies if the style will contain `:host { display: block; }`.

inlineStyle.description: Include styles inline in the component.ts file. Only CSS styles can be included inline. By default, an external styles file is created and referenced in the component.ts file.

inlineTemplate.description: Include template inline in the component.ts file. By default, an external template file is created and referenced in the component.ts file.

standalone.description: Whether the generated component is standalone.

viewEncapsulation.description: The view encapsulation strategy to use in the new component.

changeDetection.description: The change detection strategy to use in the new component.

module.description: The filename or path to the NgModule that will declare this component.

style.description: The file extension or preprocessor to use for style files, or `none` to skip generating the style file.

skipTests.description: Do not create `spec.ts` test files for the new component.

flat.description: Create the new files at the top level of the current project.

skipImport.description: Do not import this component into the owning NgModule.

selector.description: The HTML selector to use for this component.

skipSelector.description: Specifies if the component should have a selector or not.

type.description: Adds a developer-defined type to the filename, in the format `name.type.ts`.

export.description: Specifies if the component should be exported in the declaring `NgModule`. Additionally, if the project is a library, the component will be exported from the project's entry point (normally `index.ts`) if the module it belongs to is also exported or if the component is standalone.

generators.description: Generate an Angular Component.

generators.name: component-cypress-spec

schema.description: Creates a Cypress spec for a UI component that has a story.

componentPath.description: Relative path to the component file from the project root.

componentFileName.description: Component file name without the `.ts` extension.

cypressProject.description: The Cypress project to generate the stories under. By default, inferred from `projectName`.

specDirectory.description: Directory where to place the generated spec file. By default matches the value of the `componentPath` option.

generators.description: Creates a Cypress spec for a UI component that has a story.

generators.name: component-story

schema.description: Creates a `stories.ts` file for an Angular component.

componentPath.description: Relative path to the component file from the project root.

componentFileName.description: Component file name without the `.ts` extension.

generators.description: Creates a stories.ts file for a component.

generators.name: component-test

schema.description: Create a `*.cy.ts` file for Cypress component testing for an Angular component.

project.description: The name of the project where the component is located.
project.x-prompt: What project is the component located in?

componentName.description: Class name of the component to create a test for.
componentName.x-prompt: What is the class name of the component to create a test for?

componentDir.description: Relative path to the folder that contains the component from the project root.
componentDir.x-prompt: What is the path to the component directory from the project root?

componentFileName.description: File name that contains the component without the `.ts` extension.
componentFileName.x-prompt: What is the file name that contains the component?

generators.description: Creates a cypress component test file for a component.

generators.name: convert-tslint-to-eslint

schema.title: Convert an Angular project from TSLint to ESLint
schema.description: Convert an Angular project from TSLint to ESLint. NOTE: Does not work in `--dry-run mode`.

examples.description: The following will first configure the project, `myapp`, the same way a _new_ project is configured i.e. It will use Nx's new recommended ESLint config. By default, this also adds the existing TSLint configuration on top of the default ESLint config from Nx to continue checking what it checks today. This is done by migrating TSLint rules to their equivalent ESLint rules to the best of its abilities. Some TSLint rules may not have ESLint equivalents and will be reported during the conversion

If your TSLint config isn't extremely important to you, ignoring it makes this process more deterministic. Unlike the prior example, this will discard the existing TSLint configuration, meaning that the project will only have the Nx's latest recommended ESLint configuration which may be good enough for some workspaces

By default, this process removes the TSLint related dependencies and configuration once no more projects use TSLint. This can be disabled with the following flag to keep TSLint related dependencies and configuration in the repo

project.description: The name of the Angular project to convert. Please note, if the project is an Angular app with an associated Cypress e2e project, it will also attempt to convert that.
project.x-prompt: Which Angular project would you like to convert from TSLint to ESLint?

ignoreExistingTslintConfig.description: If true, it will not use existing TSLint config as a reference, it will just reset the project with the latest recommended ESLint config.
ignoreExistingTslintConfig.x-prompt: Would you like to ignore the existing TSLint config? Recommended if the TSLint config has not been altered much as it makes the new ESLint config cleaner.

removeTSLintIfNoMoreTSLintTargets.description: If this conversion leaves no more TSLint usage in the workspace, it will remove TSLint and related dependencies and configuration.
removeTSLintIfNoMoreTSLintTargets.x-prompt: Would you like to remove TSLint and its related config if there are no TSLint projects remaining after this conversion?

generators.description: Converts a project from TSLint to ESLint.

style.description: The file extension to be used for style files.

x-prompt.message: Which stylesheet format would you like to use?

skipPostInstall.description: Do not add or append `ngcc` to the `postinstall` script in `package.json`.

generators.name: karma

schema.title: Add Karma Configuration to the workspace.
schema.description: Add Karma configuration to an Nx workspace.

generators.description: Adds Karma configuration to a workspace.

generators.name: karma-project

schema.title: Create Karma Configuration for a project
schema.description: Add Karma configuration to an angular project.

generators.description: Adds Karma configuration to a project.

generators.name: library

schema.title: Create a library
schema.description: Creates an Angular library.

name.x-prompt: What name would you like to use for the library?

directory.description: A directory where the library is placed.

prefix.description: The prefix to apply to generated selectors.

simpleModuleName.description: Keep the module name simple (when using `--directory`).

skipPostInstall.description: Do not add or append `ngcc` to the `postinstall` script in `package.json`.

skipTsConfig.description: Do not update `tsconfig.json` for development experience.

routing.description: Add router configuration. See `lazy` for more information.

lazy.description: Add `RouterModule.forChild` when set to true, and a simple array of routes when set to false.

parent.description: Path to the parent route configuration using `loadChildren` or `children`, depending on what `lazy` is set to.

tags.description: Add tags to the library (used for linting).

unitTestRunner.description: Test runner to use for unit tests.

importPath.description: The library name used to import it, like `@myorg/my-awesome-lib`. Must be a valid npm name.

strict.description: Create a library with stricter type checking and build optimization options.

linter.description: The tool to use for running lint checks.

standaloneConfig.description: Split the project configuration into `<projectRoot>/project.json` rather than including it inside `workspace.json`.

compilationMode.description: Specifies the compilation mode to use. If not specified, it will default to `partial` for publishable libraries and to `full` for buildable libraries. The `full` value can not be used for publishable libraries.

setParserOptionsProject.description: Whether or not to configure the ESLint `parserOptions.project` option. We do not do this by default for lint performance reasons.

addTailwind.description: Whether to configure Tailwind CSS for the application. It can only be used with buildable and publishable libraries. Non-buildable libraries will use the application's Tailwind configuration.

skipModule.description: Whether to skip the creation of a default module when generating the library.

standalone.description: Generate a library that uses a standalone component instead of a module as the entry point.

displayBlock.description: Specifies if the component generated style will contain `:host { display: block; }`. Disclaimer: This option is only valid when `--standalone` is set to `true`.

inlineStyle.description: Include styles inline in the component.ts file. Only CSS styles can be included inline. By default, an external styles file is created and referenced in the component.ts file. Disclaimer: This option is only valid when `--standalone` is set to `true`.

inlineTemplate.description: Include template inline in the component.ts file. By default, an external template file is created and referenced in the component.ts file. Disclaimer: This option is only valid when `--standalone` is set to `true`.

viewEncapsulation.description: The view encapsulation strategy to use in the new component. Disclaimer: This option is only valid when `--standalone` is set to `true`.

changeDetection.description: The change detection strategy to use in the new component. Disclaimer: This option is only valid when `--standalone` is set to `true`.

style.description: The file extension or preprocessor to use for style files, or `none` to skip generating the style file. Disclaimer: This option is only valid when `--standalone` is set to `true`.

skipTests.description: Do not create `spec.ts` test files for the new component. Disclaimer: This option is only valid when `--standalone` is set to `true`.

selector.description: The HTML selector to use for this component. Disclaimer: This option is only valid when `--standalone` is set to `true`.

skipSelector.description: Specifies if the component should have a selector or not. Disclaimer: This option is only valid when `--standalone` is set to `true`.

generators.description: Creates an Angular library.

library.description: The name of the library to create the secondary entry point for.
library.x-prompt: What library would you like to create the secondary entry point for?

skipModule.description: Skip generating a module for the secondary entry point.

generators.description: Creates a secondary entry point for an Angular publishable library.

directory.description: The directory of the new application.

style.description: The file extension to be used for style files.

unitTestRunner.description: Test runner to use for unit tests.

e2eTestRunner.description: Test runner to use for end to end (E2E) tests.

backendProject.description: Backend project that provides data to this application. This sets up `proxy.config.json`.

strict.description: Create an application with stricter type checking and build optimization options.

standaloneConfig.description: Split the project configuration into `<projectRoot>/project.json` rather than including it inside `workspace.json`.

setParserOptionsProject.description: Whether or not to configure the ESLint `parserOptions.project` option. We do not do this by default for lint performance reasons.

schema.title: Nx Angular Move
schema.description: Move an Angular project to another folder in the workspace.

generators.name: convert-to-with-mf

schema.title: Convert to withModuleFederation Generator Options Schema
schema.description:
Converts an old micro frontend configuration to use the new withModuleFederation helper. It will run successfully if the following conditions are met: 
 - Is either a host or remote application 
 - Shared npm package configurations have not been modified 
 - Name used to identify the Micro Frontend application matches the project name 

{% callout type="warning" title="Overrides" %}This generator will overwrite your webpack config. If you have additional custom configuration in your config file, it will be lost!{% /callout %}.

project.description: The name of the micro frontend project to migrate.
project.x-prompt: What micro frontend project would you like to migrate?

generators.description:
Converts an old micro frontend configuration to use the new withModuleFederation helper. It will run successfully if the following conditions are met: 
 - Is either a host or remote application 
 - Shared npm package configurations have not been modified 
 - Name used to identify the Micro Frontend application matches the project name 

{% callout type="warning" title="Overrides" %}This generator will overwrite your webpack config. If you have additional custom configuration in your config file, it will be lost!{% /callout %}

generators.name: ng-add

schema.title: Angular plugin initialization
schema.description: Migrates an Angular CLI workspace to Nx or adds the Angular plugin to an Nx workspace. NOTE: Does not work in the `--dry-run` mode.

npmScope.description: Npm scope for importing libs. NOTE: only used if running the generator in an Angular CLI workspace.

defaultBase.description: Default base branch for affected. NOTE: only used if running the generator in an Angular CLI workspace.

preserveAngularCliLayout.description: Preserve the Angular CLI layout instead of moving the app into apps. NOTE: only used if running the generator in an Angular CLI workspace.

unitTestRunner.description: Test runner to use for unit tests. NOTE: only used if running the generator in an Nx workspace.

e2eTestRunner.description: Test runner to use for end to end (e2e) tests. NOTE: only used if running the generator in an Nx workspace.

skipFormat.description: Skip formatting files. NOTE: only used if running the generator in an Nx workspace.

linter.description: The tool to use for running lint checks. NOTE: only used if running the generator in an Nx workspace.

style.description: The file extension to be used for style files. NOTE: only used if running the generator in an Nx workspace.

skipPackageJson.description: Do not add dependencies to `package.json`. NOTE: only used if running the generator in an Nx workspace.

skipPostInstall.description: Do not add or append `ngcc` to the `postinstall` script in `package.json`. NOTE: only used if running the generator in an Nx workspace.

generators.name: ngrx

schema.title: Add NgRx support to an application or library.
schema.description: Adds NgRx support to an application or library.

name.description: Name of the NgRx feature state, such as `products` or `users`. Recommended to use the plural form of the name.
name.x-prompt: What name would you like to use for the NgRx feature state? An example would be `users`.

module.description: The path to the `NgModule` where the feature state will be registered. The host directory will create/use the new state directory.
module.x-prompt: What is the path to the module where this NgRx state should be registered?

directory.description: The name of the folder used to contain/group the generated NgRx files.

root.description: Setup root or feature state management with NgRx.
root.x-prompt: Is this the root state of the application?

facade.description: Create a Facade class for the the feature.
facade.x-prompt: Would you like to use a Facade with your NgRx state?

skipImport.description: Generate NgRx feature files without registering the feature in the NgModule.

minimal.description: Only register the root state management setup or feature state.

skipPackageJson.description: Do not update the `package.json` with NgRx dependencies.

barrels.description: Use barrels to re-export actions, state and selectors.

generators.description: Adds NgRx support to an application or library.

schema.title: SCAM Generator Options Schema
schema.description: Creates a new, generic Angular component definition in the given or default project.

path.description: The path at which to create the component file, relative to the current workspace. Default is a folder with the same name as the component in the project root.

name.x-prompt: What name would you like to use for the component?

displayBlock.description: Specifies if the style will contain `:host { display: block; }`.

inlineStyle.description: Include styles inline in the `component.ts` file. Only CSS styles can be included inline. By default, an external styles file is created and referenced in the `component.ts` file.

inlineTemplate.description: Include template inline in the `component.ts` file. By default, an external template file is created and referenced in the `component.ts` file.

viewEncapsulation.description: The view encapsulation strategy to use in the new component.

changeDetection.description: The change detection strategy to use in the new component.

style.description: The file extension or preprocessor to use for style files, or 'none' to skip generating the style file.

skipTests.description: Do not create `spec.ts` test files for the new component.

inlineScam.description: Create the `NgModule` in the same file as the component.

flat.description: Create the new files at the top level of the current project.

selector.description: The `HTML` selector to use for this component.

skipSelector.description: Specifies if the component should have a selector or not.

type.description: Adds a developer-defined type to the filename, in the format `name.type.ts`.

prefix.description: The prefix to apply to the generated component selector.

export.description: Specifies if the SCAM should be exported from the project's entry point (normally `index.ts`). It only applies to libraries.

generators.description: Generate a component with an accompanying Single Component Angular Module (SCAM).

generators.name: scam-directive

schema.title: SCAM Directive Generator Options Schema
schema.description: Creates a new, generic Angular directive definition in the given or default project.

path.description: The path at which to create the directive file, relative to the current workspace. Default is a folder with the same name as the directive in the project root.

name.x-prompt: What name would you like to use for the directive?

skipTests.description: Do not create `spec.ts` test files for the new directive.

inlineScam.description: Create the `NgModule` in the same file as the Directive.

flat.description: Create the new files at the top level of the current project.

selector.description: The `HTML` selector to use for this directive.

project.x-prompt: What project would you like to add the Tailwind CSS setup?

buildTarget.description: The name of the target used to build the project. This option only applies to buildable/publishable libraries.

generators.name: stories

schema.title: Create Storybook stories/specs
schema.description: Creates Storybook stories/specs for all Angular components declared in a project.

name.description: Project for which to generate stories.
name.x-prompt: What's the name of the project for which you want to generate stories?

generateCypressSpecs.description: Specifies whether to automatically generate `*.spec.ts` files in the Cypress e2e app generated by the `cypress-configure` generator.
generateCypressSpecs.x-prompt: Do you want to generate Cypress specs as well?

cypressProject.description: The Cypress project to generate the stories under. This is inferred from `name` by default.

ignorePaths.description: Paths to ignore when looking for components.

schema.examplesFile:
This generator will generate stories for all your components in your project.

```bash
nx g @nrwl/angular:stories project-name
```

You can read more about how this generator works, in the [Storybook for Angular overview page](/storybook/overview-angular#auto-generate-stories).

When running this generator, you will be prompted to provide the following:

- The `name` of the project you want to generate the configuration for.
- Whether you want to `generateCypressSpecs`. If you choose `yes`, a test file is going to be generated in the project's Cypress e2e app for each of your components.

You must provide a `name` for the generator to work.

There are a number of other options available. Let's take a look at some examples.

## Examples

### Ignore certain paths when generating stories

```bash
nx g @nrwl/angular:stories ui --ignorePaths=libs/ui/src/not-stories/**,**/**/src/**/*.other.*
```

This will generate stories for all the components in the `ui` project, except for the ones in the `libs/ui/src/not-stories` directory, and also for components that their file name is of the pattern `*.other.*`.

This is useful if you have a project that contains components that are not meant to be used in isolation, but rather as part of a larger component.

generators.description: Creates stories/specs for all components declared in a project.

generators.name: storybook-configuration

schema.title: Adds Storybook configuration to a project.
schema.description: Adds Storybook configuration to a project to be able to use and create stories.

name.description: Project for which to generate Storybook configuration.
name.x-prompt: For which project do you want to generate Storybook configuration?

configureCypress.description: Specifies whether to configure Cypress or not.
configureCypress.x-prompt: Configure a Cypress e2e app to run against the storybook instance?

generateStories.description: Specifies whether to automatically generate `*.stories.ts` files for components declared in this project or not.
generateStories.x-prompt: Automatically generate *.stories.ts files for components declared in this project?

generateCypressSpecs.description: Specifies whether to automatically generate test files in the generated Cypress e2e app.
generateCypressSpecs.x-prompt: Automatically generate test files in the generated Cypress e2e app?

cypressDirectory.description: A directory where the Cypress project will be placed. Placed at the root by default.

linter.description: The tool to use for running lint checks.

tsConfiguration.description: Configure your project with TypeScript. Generate main.ts and preview.ts files, instead of main.js and preview.js.

ignorePaths.description: Paths to ignore when looking for components.

schema.examplesFile:
This generator will set up Storybook for your Angular project.

```bash
nx g @nrwl/angular:storybook-configuration project-name
```

You can read more about how this generator works, in the [Storybook for Angular overview page](/storybook/overview-angular#generate-storybook-configuration-for-an-angular-project).

When running this generator, you will be prompted to provide the following:

- The `name` of the project you want to generate the configuration for.
- Whether you want to `configureCypress`. If you choose `yes`, a Cypress e2e app will be created (or configured) to run against the project's Storybook instance. You can read more about this in the [Storybook for Angular - Cypress section](/storybook/overview-angular#cypress-tests-for-stories).
- Whether you want to `generateStories` for the components in your project. If you choose `yes`, a `.stories.ts` file will be generated next to each of your components in your project.
- Whether you want to `generateCypressSpecs`. If you choose `yes`, a test file is going to be generated in the project's Cypress e2e app for each of your components.
- Whether you want to `configureTestRunner`. If you choose `yes`, a `test-storybook` target will be generated in your project's `project.json`, with a command to invoke the [Storybook `test-runner`](https://storybook.js.org/docs/react/writing-tests/test-runner).

You must provide a `name` for the generator to work.

There are a number of other options available. Let's take a look at some examples.

## Examples

### Generate Storybook configuration using TypeScript

```bash
nx g @nrwl/angular:storybook-configuration ui --tsConfiguration=true
```

This will generate a Storybook configuration for the `ui` project using TypeScript for the Storybook configuration files (the files inside the `.storybook` directory).

### Ignore certain paths when generating stories

```bash
nx g @nrwl/angular:storybook-configuration ui --generateStories=true --ignorePaths=libs/ui/src/not-stories/**,**/**/src/**/*.other.*,apps/my-app/**/*.something.ts
```

This will generate a Storybook configuration for the `ui` project and generate stories for all components in the `libs/ui/src/lib` directory, except for the ones in the `libs/ui/src/not-stories` directory, and the ones in the `apps/my-app` directory that end with `.something.ts`, and also for components that their file name is of the pattern `*.other.*`.

This is useful if you have a project that contains components that are not meant to be used in isolation, but rather as part of a larger component.

generators.description: Adds Storybook configuration to a project.

executors.name: webpack-browser

schema.title: Schema for Webpack Browser
schema.description:
The webpack-browser executor is very similar to the standard browser builder provided by the Angular Devkit. It allows you to build your Angular application to a build artifact that can be hosted online. There are some key differences:   
- Supports Custom Webpack Configurations  
- Supports Incremental Building
schema.examplesFile:
##### Using a custom webpack configuration

The executor supports providing a path to a custom webpack configuration. This allows you to customize how your Angular application is built. It currently supports the following types of webpack configurations:

- `object`
- `Function`
- `Promise<object|Function>`

The executor will merge the provided configuration with the webpack configuration that Angular Devkit uses. The merge order is:

- Angular Devkit Configuration
- Provided Configuration

To use a custom webpack configuration when building your Angular application, change the `build` target in your `project.json` to match the following:

```typescript
"build": {
    "executor": "@nrwl/angular:webpack-browser",
    "options": {
        ...
        "customWebpackConfig": {
          "path": "apps/appName/webpack.config.js"
        }
    }
}
```

##### Incrementally Building your Application

The executor supports incrementally building your Angular application by building the workspace libraries it depends on _(that have been marked as buildable)_ and then building your application using the built source of the libraries.

This can improve build time as the building of the workspace libraries can be cached, meaning they only have to be rebuilt if they have changed.

> Note: There may be some additional overhead in the linking of the built libraries' sources which may reduce the overall improvement in build time. Therefore this approach only benefits large applications and would likely have a negative impact on small and medium applications.  
> You can read more about when to use incremental builds [here](/more-concepts/incremental-builds#when-should-i-use-incremental-builds).

To allow your Angular application to take advantage of incremental building, change the `build` target in your `project.json` to match the following:

```typescript
"build": {
    "executor": "@nrwl/angular:webpack-browser",
    "options": {
        ...
        "buildLibsFromSource": false
    }
}
```

followSymlinks.description: Allow glob patterns to follow symlink directories. This allows subdirectories of the symlink to be searched.

input.description: The input directory path in which to apply 'glob'. Defaults to the project root.

ignore.description: An array of globs to ignore.

main.description: The full path for the main entry point to the app, relative to the current workspace.

polyfills.description: The full path for the polyfills file, relative to the current workspace.

tsConfig.description: The full path for the TypeScript configuration file, relative to the current workspace.

scripts.description: Global scripts to be included in the build.

bundleName.description: The bundle name for this extra entry point.

inject.description: If the bundle will be referenced in the HTML file.

styles.description: Global styles to be included in the build.

bundleName.description: The bundle name for this extra entry point.

inject.description: If the bundle will be referenced in the HTML file.

inlineStyleLanguage.description: The stylesheet language to use for the application's inline component styles.

stylePreprocessorOptions.description: Options to pass to style preprocessors.

includePaths.description: Paths to include. Paths will be resolved to project root.

optimization.description: Enables optimization of the build output. Including minification of scripts and styles, tree-shaking, dead-code elimination, inlining of critical CSS and fonts inlining. For more information, see https://angular.io/guide/workspace-config#optimization-configuration.

scripts.description: Enables optimization of the scripts output.

styles.description: Enables optimization of the styles output.

minify.description: Minify CSS definitions by removing extraneous whitespace and comments, merging identifiers and minimizing values.

inlineCritical.description: Extract and inline critical CSS definitions to improve first paint time.

fonts.description: Enables optimization for fonts. This option requires internet access. `HTTPS_PROXY` environment variable can be used to specify a proxy server.

inline.description: Reduce render blocking requests by inlining external Google Fonts and Adobe Fonts CSS definitions in the application's HTML index file. This option requires internet access. `HTTPS_PROXY` environment variable can be used to specify a proxy server.

fileReplacements.description: Replace compilation source files with other compilation source files in the build.

outputPath.description:
The full path for the new output directory, relative to the current workspace.

By default, writes output to a folder named dist/ in the current project.

resourcesOutputPath.description: The path where style resources will be placed, relative to outputPath.

aot.description: Build using Ahead of Time compilation.

sourceMap.description: Output source maps for scripts and styles. For more information, see https://angular.io/guide/workspace-config#source-map-configuration.

scripts.description: Output source maps for all scripts.

styles.description: Output source maps for all styles.

hidden.description: Output source maps used for error reporting tools.

vendorChunk.description: Generate a seperate bundle containing only vendor libraries. This option should only used for development.

commonChunk.description: Generate a seperate bundle containing code used across multiple bundles.

baseHref.description: Base url for the application being built.

deployUrl.description: URL where files will be deployed.
deployUrl.x-deprecated: Use `baseHref` option, `APP_BASE_HREF` DI token or a combination of both instead. For more information, see https://angular.io/guide/deployment#the-deploy-url.

verbose.description: Adds more details to output logging.

progress.description: Log progress to the console while building.

i18nMissingTranslation.description: How to handle missing translations for i18n.

i18nDuplicateTranslation.description: How to handle duplicate translations for i18n.

localize.description: Translate the bundles in one or more locales.

oneOf.description: List of locales ID's to translate.

outputHashing.description: Define the output filename cache-busting hashing mode.

poll.description: Enable and define the file watching poll time period in milliseconds.

deleteOutputPath.description: Delete the output path before building.

preserveSymlinks.description: Do not use the real path when resolving modules. If unset then will default to `true` if NodeJS option --preserve-symlinks is set.

extractLicenses.description: Extract all licenses in a separate file.

buildOptimizer.description: Enables advanced build optimizations when using the 'aot' option.

namedChunks.description: Use file name for lazy loaded chunks.

subresourceIntegrity.description: Enables the use of subresource integrity validation.

serviceWorker.description: Generates a service worker config for production builds.

index.description: Configures the generation of the application's HTML index.

oneOf.description: The path of a file to use for the application's HTML index. The filename of the specified path will be used for the generated file and will be created in the root of the application's configured output path.

input.description: The path of a file to use for the application's generated HTML index.

output.description: The output path of the application's generated HTML index file. The full provided path will be used and will be considered relative to the application's configured output path.

statsJson.description: Generates a 'stats.json' file which can be analyzed using tools such as 'webpack-bundle-analyzer'.

budgets.description: Budget thresholds to ensure parts of your application stay within boundaries which you set.

maximumWarning.description: The maximum threshold for warning relative to the baseline.

maximumError.description: The maximum threshold for error relative to the baseline.

minimumWarning.description: The minimum threshold for warning relative to the baseline.

minimumError.description: The minimum threshold for error relative to the baseline.

warning.description: The threshold for warning relative to the baseline (min & max).

error.description: The threshold for error relative to the baseline (min & max).

webWorkerTsConfig.description: TypeScript configuration for Web Worker modules.

crossOrigin.description: Define the crossorigin attribute setting of elements that provide CORS support.

allowedCommonJsDependencies.description: A list of CommonJS packages that are allowed to be used without a build time warning.

path.description: Path to additional webpack configuration, relative to the workspace root.

buildLibsFromSource.description: Read buildable libraries from source instead of building them separately.

followSymlinks.description: Allow glob patterns to follow symlink directories. This allows subdirectories of the symlink to be searched.

input.description: The input directory path in which to apply 'glob'. Defaults to the project root.

ignore.description: An array of globs to ignore.

maximumWarning.description: The maximum threshold for warning relative to the baseline.

maximumError.description: The maximum threshold for error relative to the baseline.

minimumWarning.description: The minimum threshold for warning relative to the baseline.

minimumError.description: The minimum threshold for error relative to the baseline.

warning.description: The threshold for warning relative to the baseline (min & max).

error.description: The threshold for error relative to the baseline (min & max).

executors.description:
The `webpack-browser` executor is very similar to the standard `browser` builder provided by the Angular Devkit. It allows you to build your Angular application to a build artifact that can be hosted online. There are some key differences:   
- Supports Custom Webpack Configurations  
- Supports Incremental Building

executors.name: webpack-dev-server

schema.title: Schema for Webpack Dev Server
schema.description: The webpack-dev-server executor is very similar to the standard dev server builder provided by the Angular Devkit. It is usually used in tandem with `@nrwl/angular:webpack-browser` when your Angular application uses a custom webpack configuration.

browserTarget.description: A browser builder target to serve in the format of `project:target[:configuration]`. You can also pass in more than one configuration name as a comma-separated list. Example: `project:target:production,staging`.

proxyConfig.description: Proxy configuration file. For more information, see https://angular.io/guide/build#proxying-to-a-backend-server.

sslKey.description: SSL key to use for serving HTTPS.

sslCert.description: SSL certificate to use for serving HTTPS.

headers.description: Custom HTTP headers to be added to all responses.

open.description: Opens the url in default browser.

verbose.description: Adds more details to output logging.

liveReload.description: Whether to reload the page on change, using live-reload.

publicHost.description: The URL that the browser client (or live-reload client, if enabled) should use to connect to the development server. Use for a complex dev server setup, such as one with reverse proxies.

allowedHosts.description: List of hosts that are allowed to access the dev server.

servePath.description: The pathname where the app will be served.

disableHostCheck.description: Don't verify connected clients are part of allowed hosts.

poll.description: Enable and define the file watching poll time period in milliseconds.

buildLibsFromSource.description: Read buildable libraries from source instead of building them separately. If not set, it will take the value specified in the `browserTarget` options, or it will default to `true` if it's also not set in the `browserTarget` options.

executors.description: The `webpack-dev-server` executor is very similar to the standard `dev-server` builder provided by the Angular Devkit. It is usually used in tandem with `@nrwl/angular:webpack-browser` when your Angular application uses a custom webpack configuration.

executors.name: module-federation-dev-server

schema.title: Schema for Module Federation Dev Server
schema.description: The module-federation-dev-server executor is reserved exclusively for use with host Module Federation applications. It allows the user to specify which remote applications should be served with the host.

browserTarget.description: A browser builder target to serve in the format of `project:target[:configuration]`. You can also pass in more than one configuration name as a comma-separated list. Example: `project:target:production,staging`.

proxyConfig.description: Proxy configuration file. For more information, see https://angular.io/guide/build#proxying-to-a-backend-server.

sslKey.description: SSL key to use for serving HTTPS.

sslCert.description: SSL certificate to use for serving HTTPS.

headers.description: Custom HTTP headers to be added to all responses.

open.description: Opens the url in default browser.

verbose.description: Adds more details to output logging.

liveReload.description: Whether to reload the page on change, using live-reload.

publicHost.description: The URL that the browser client (or live-reload client, if enabled) should use to connect to the development server. Use for a complex dev server setup, such as one with reverse proxies.

allowedHosts.description: List of hosts that are allowed to access the dev server.

servePath.description: The pathname where the app will be served.

disableHostCheck.description: Don't verify connected clients are part of allowed hosts.

poll.description: Enable and define the file watching poll time period in milliseconds.

devRemotes.description: List of remote applications to run in development mode (i.e. using serve target).

executors.description: The module-federation-dev-server executor is reserved exclusively for use with host Module Federation applications. It allows the user to specify which remote applications should be served with the host.

executors.name: file-server

schema.title: File Server
schema.description: Serve a web application from a folder.

sslKey.description: SSL key to use for serving `HTTPS`.

sslCert.description: SSL certificate to use for serving `HTTPS`.

proxyUrl.description: URL to proxy unhandled requests to.

proxyOptions.description: Options for the proxy used by `http-server`.

spa.description: Redirect 404 errors to index.html (useful for SPA's).

executors.description: Serve a web application from a folder.
